FBL-6083 B01-F09 Updates to Email Manager - add new rule, generate and the send email

comments.author: Jonathan Kernan
comments.comment:
Would it make more sense to move this logic into OCCase?
```java public List<TaEnum<PointsOfContactCaseLinkReason>> getPointOfContactLinkReasons() { getOCCase().getPointOfContactLinkReasons(); } ```
To me, this is very much FDP logic and we would have a clearer separation of interface and implementation.
On a side note, we have an interface com.fineos.common.enums.PointsOfContactCaseLinkReason
This has two references to enums in billing:
```java long ACCESS_BILLING_ACCOUNT_IN_EMPLOYER_VIEWPOINT = UNKNOWN + 26001; long RECEIVE_EMAIL_WHEN_BILL_PUBLISHED = UNKNOWN + 26002; ```
Can this be removed altogether? I can't see any references to these.
If we have anything like this where we abolutely have to hardcode enum instances or subset names, it might be worth extending com.fineos.fipfacade.enums.PointsOfContactCaseLinkReason in Billing and specifying the instance IDs or subset names there.

comments.author: Jonathan Kernan
comments.comment: Just a thought. Should we be exposing the remove method in WebWidgetContainer rather than WebPage? This will allow to remove direct child widgets of the page only.

reviewTimeLines.summary: FBL-6405:Validation message raised when user changes from Billing Address to Policyholder\'s Address

comments.author: Jonathan Kernan
comments.comment:
Not sure if we should store the widget here.
This essentially holds a reference to the last EditAddressWidget we've created. If two different pages had this widget, calling remove() might try to remove the wrong one.
PageA AddressWidgetA PageB AddressWidgetB
If the pages are loaded in this order then calling remove(pageA) would try to remove addressWidgetB if we're treating this class as a lazy singleton(public constructor still available).

comments.author: Hugo Dias
comments.comment: Why not a DB Query? If an employee has 10 occupations we are going to iterate for the 10.

comments.author: Daniel Dardis
comments.comment:
Yes, could be a DB Query. What I've tried to do was finding a balance between solution and implementation effort, some points we have to consider:
- Person and Occupation are objects from claims so we are not able to query them directly without a FIP violation - There is no such method on Claims currently, so I'd have to create this on claims side and expose it as Manager and Entity (Facade). - Naturally a person have few occupations (not so many iterations).
Do you think it is worth?

comments.author: Hugo Dias
comments.comment: We can drop this, but we should ask Gareth's opinion. I don't feel confortable with loops to find elements in the DB.

comments.author: Hugo Dias
comments.comment:
Why a TreeMap? Without a Comparator a TreeMap is a waste of resources and a lack of Performance.
Depending on the purpose, if you need to preserve the entry order use LinkedHashMap or if is just a bag use HashMap.
